bibl.title: Report from Alexander N. Stark to the Surgeon General, June 15, 1900

div1.p: Stark gives a detailed report on the outbreak of yellow fever in Quemados, Cuba and Columbia Barracks, Cuba. Stark claims that Mrs. Henry S. King is the first case of yellow fever. A Medical Board with Ames, Lazear, and three Cubans is created to investigate the outbreak. Stark highly commends the doctors and staff at Post Hospital. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Report from Alexander N. Stark to the Surgeon General, June 15, 1900
div1.opener:
Starks first report on the Quemados
epidemic - summer 1900 June 15, 1900
(see Howard's report of June 18
POST HOSPITAL COLUMBIA BARRACKS
June 15th, 1900.
TO THE
SURGEON GENERAL, U.S. ARMY,
WASHINGTON, D.C.
SIR:-
div1.p:
I have the honor to submit the following special report upon
an outbreak of yellow fever in the town of Quemados, Cuba, and Columbia
Barracks.

On Monday, May 21st, 1900, two local physicians of Quemados reported
to the Chief Surgeon of the Department that they were in attendance
upon a suspicious case of fever at number 20 General Lee St., the pa-
tient being a packer in the 7th Cavalry corral at Columbia Barracks.
By Tuesday night it was definitely decided that the case was genuine
yellow fever. On Wednesday morning, May 23rd, the patient and his wife
were removed to the infectious wards at Columbia Barracks.

In addition to the two removed, the house was occupied by a Sig-
nal Sergeant, his wife and little daughter, an American dentist, several
young clerks, and the lessee of the house, also an American, all of whom
were promptly placed in quarantine.

On Wednesday, May the 23rd, Sergeant Sherwood developed suspicious
symptoms. On Thursday, May 24th, he was removed to the infectious wards
at Columbia Barracks. The dentist and other occupants of the house save Mrs. Sherwood & daughter, were
removed to other quarters for observation, their effects being retained.

On the evening of May 24th, Private Balentine, Co. “D” 8th Infantry,
was admitted to the receiving ward at Post Hospital with very suspicious
symptoms, and on the morning of the 26th of May, the diagnosis of yellow
fever being definitely settled, he was removed to the infectious wards.
Page.2.
In the interim the quarters of Co. “D” 8th Infantry were carefully dis-
infected.

On May 27th, the little daughter of Sergeant Sherwood had an attack
of indigestion from the ingestion of a large quantity of guava paste,
but the trouble not yeilding promptly to treatment and other symptoms
of extremely suspicious nature arising, on the morning of may 31st, she
was removed to the infectious wards accompanied by her mother who on
that day showed a slight elevation of temperature. Sergeant Sherwood
died on the same day, May 31st. The autopsy was performed by A.A. Surgeon
Lazear, U.S.A., and the diagnosis of yellow fever was confirmed. Mrs.
Sherwood developed the characteristic symptoms of the disease on June
3rd, 1900. A careful examination into the probable origin of the infec-
tion established the fact that the house number 20 General Lee St. was
the focus beyond doubt.

Mrs. King, the wife of the packer, acknowledged on close questioning
that she had been sick for several days prior to her husband's seizure,
had bled profusely from the gums, and though she felt exhausted attribu-
ted her sweakness and loss of blood to carious teeth, and therefore did
not deem the services of a physician necessary. She is beyond doubt the
first case of yellow fever in the present outbreak. The Kings lead a
blameless existence, did not visit the city of Havana, nor had these pa-
tients purchased any clothing or bedding purchased in any Cuban town. They arrived
on April 1st, having just left the town of Santa Clara where an outbreak
of yellow fever among those soldiers who had married native women began
on May 10th. In addition to their clothes, the Kings brought with them
from Santa Clara two bed quilts.
Page.3.

While it is thought by some that the effects of the Kings were
responsible for the introduction of yellow fever I cannot entertain that
view, beleiving as I do that the infection was latent in the house, re-
quiring only suitable conditions for its development, which conditions
were provided by the incessant rain of nineteendays duration previous
to the first case of sickness. While the house and its cess-pools were
in excellent condition (sanitary), and while the same may be said of
some of the other residences in which infection occurred, it is well to
remember that the sub-soil of Cuban towns has through several genera-
tions become honey-combed with cess-pools that having served their time
of usefulness have been closed and their location forgotten. In addi-
tion to this, I hold it impossible to thoroughly disinfect any house here
in which infection has probably occurred frequently in the past, the
disease being denominated, infection fever or el borras, if the infection
were in the first instance a child or in the second an adult Cuban, when
in fact both these diseases are yellow fever pure and simple, and when
the house is constructed of heavy masonary with tiled floors.

Sergeant Sherwood was employed at the Cable Office in Havana be-
tween the hours of 8 A.M. and 4 P.M., and his habits were exaemplary. The
other occupants of the house had not been exposed to any infection, nor
have they been sick up to the present time.

The house is situated near the corner of Real and General Lee Sts.,
and is at the summit of a slight hill, General Lee St. terminating with a
gentle fall at the Marianao railroad track which forms the boundary be-
tween town and reservation.

Careful interrogation and investigation has failed to discover the
source of Private Balentine's infection, and this case must remain one
of those whose origin is merged in obscurity.
Page 4.

On May 31st, a teamster employed by the Chief Quartermaster and
living at a corral in the rear of Department Headquarters was admitted
to the receiving ward suffering with general pain and fever, presumably
due to a slight orchitis following a recent attack of mumps, but the dis-
covery of albumen and bile stained casts in his urine, together with de-
pressed pulse and congested conjunctivae, warranted his removal to the
infectious wards with the diagnosis of yellow fever, which diagnosis was
subsequently confirmed. This teamster had been in Quemados but a month
and lived in a well cared for camp, though his duties compelled his pre-
sence at all manner of localities. Interrogation has failed to assign
any cause for this teamster's infection beyond the fact that he worked
for several days at the dumping ground of the town. The veracity of in-
dividuals of this man's class cannot always be depended upon, and it is
presumed that with his fellows he was in the habit of visiting ques-
tionable resorts in pursuit of recreation.

On June 3rd, Private Teeter, orderly for the Chief Surgeon and liv-
ing at 102 Real St., in close proximity to number 20 General Lee St., was
admitted to the receiving ward with suspicious symptoms, and on June 4th
was removed to the infectious wards with the diagnosis of yellow fever,
which diagnosis was subsequently confirmed. The focus of infection in
this case is presumably the house. This house was occupied by Sergeant
Reilly and wife, several young men employed in the Post Quartermaster's
office, and Private Teeter. The remaining occupants, save Sergeant
Reilly and wife, were removed on June 5th into tents with only the cloth-
es they wore, the rest being retained for disinfection. On the same day
Sergeant Reilly complained of severe head-ache and pains in his back,
and on June 6th he and his wife were removed to the infectious wards,
he with yellow fever, and she for observation.
Page 5

On Friday, June 8th, two young Hebrews owning a talior shop on Gene-
ral Lee St. directly opposite number 20, the first focus, were taken to
the Municipal Hospital with yellow fever, one dying the following day
and the other on Monday June the 11th, both having been ill three days
prior to their appeal for medical assistance at the Post Hospital where
the disease was recognized.

On June 8th, Mr. Schenck, Quartermaster employed, one of the occupants
of number 102 Real St., was taken ill, displaying suspicious symptoms
which speedily developed into yellow fever.

On June 9th, teamster Hoagland, an employe in the Post corral and
living in the corral, was admitted to the receiving ward with suspicious
symptoms, and on June 10th was removed to the infectious wards with
yellow fever. This man had been in the habit of frequenting houses of pros-
titution and undoubtedly contracted the disease in one of them.

Corporal Walker, Troop “H” 7th Cavalry, living in barracks, was admit-
ted to the receiving ward on the evening of June 10th with temperature,
and on as June 12th was removed to the infectious wards with yellow fever.
Interrogation disclosed the fact that this man had a native mistress
living on Real St., directly across the street from number 20 General Lee
St., and was in the habit of visiting her after roll-call at night.

On Sunday, June 10th, a Hebrew tailor owning a shop opposite No.
“20 General Lee St was admitted to the Municipal Hospital with yellow
fever, the house being the focus of infection.

On the evening of June 11th, Major Edmunds, 1st. Infantry, living at
at number 27 General Lee St., was taken sick, and on Wednesday morning the
diagnosis of yellow fever was made. On Wednesday night Mrs. Edmunds was
taken sick, and on Thursday her case was diagnosed as yellow fever, the
diagnosis in both cases being subsequently confirmed. Again the house
Page 6.
was a focus of infection.

On Wednesday, June 13th, an aged lady of American birth living at
number 16 General Lee St., directly opposite the residence of Major Ed-
munds, was taken sick, and on Thursday the diease was pronounced yellow
fever. Three months prior to the illness of this lady a young Cuban girl
whose family occupied this house died suddenly after an illness of a few
days, the disease being promuonced by the local physicians ‘perniciosa’.
This aged lady had been in the house but 10 days before her illness,
having come from New York for the purpose of visiting her Cuban grand-
children.

On Friday, June 15th, an Austrian, proprietor of a small restaurant
on General Lee St. four doors from the railroad, was removed to the Muni-
cipal Hospital with yellow fever, having been ill four days before the
fact was discovered. The house in this instance was constructed of wood
and the back-yard was filthy.

On Friday evening, June 15th, a German carpenter working on the new
wards at the Post Hospital was admitted to the receiving ward, and exam-
ination disclosed the fact that though ill for several days previous he
had attempted to work in a desultory manner until compelled to desist
from exhaustion. His case was easily diagnosed as yellow fever, and he
was immediately removed to the infectious wards. This man lived on San
Ygnacio St. in Havana, a noted locality in the past for yellow fever, and
unquestionably contracted the disease there.

A Board, composed of three Cuban physicians, A.A. Surgeons Ames and
Lazear, was immediately formed at the appearance of the first case to
pronounce upon all subsequent cases deemed suspicious, and by this Board
the diagnosis was made in every case.
Page 7

Every precaution was immediately taken in both town and Post to
prevent the spread of the disease, and it is believed that this end has
been attained. A supplemental report will be rendered later.

In conclusion, I desire to commend to your consideration A.A. Surgeon
Roger Post Ames, U.S.A., to whose excellent judgement and professional
skill the low mortality is largely due, A.A. Surgeon Jesse W. Lazear, by whose
skill in microscopy and chemistry the diagnosis of all cases was faci-
litated, Privates Lambert, McNeer, Fanning, and Colbey, Hospital Corps U.S.A.,
for their untiring attention to duty, Private Lambert alone being immune,
Contract nurses Anne E. Obrien, Phoebe Girault, Kate S.M. Ledlie, and Ella M.
Gillen, for their devotion to duty.
div1.closer:
Very respectfully,
Your obedient servant, A. N. Stark, Capt. & Asst. Surgeon, U.S. Army.,
R G E O N.
